item.title: A-Train: All Aboard! Tourism coming to Switch 2 on December 18
item.content:encoded:
• Switch 2

A 2,000 yen upgrade from the Switch version.

Artdink has announced A-Train: All Aboard! Tourism – Nintendo Switch 2 Edition for Switch 2. It will launch on December 18 with English, Japanese, Korean, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese language options.

A-Train: All Aboard! Tourism first launched for Switch on March 12, 2021 worldwide, followed by PC via Steam on December 7, 2021.

Users who own the Switch version will be able to upgrade to the Switch 2 version by purchasing an “Upgrade Pass” for 2,000 yen (2,200 yen with tax).

In Japan, a physical edition will be available for 9,460 yen (10,406 yen with tax), while the digital edition will be priced at 8,980 yen (9,878 yen with tax). Like most Nintendo Switch 2 Edition releases, the physical edition will ship with the Switch version and Switch 2 version “Upgrade Pass” on the game card.

A-Train: All Aboard! Tourism – Nintendo Switch 2 Edition adds the following features:

  • “Nintendo Switch 2 Mode” – New mode allowing you to place more trains, cars, and blueprints.
    • Trains: 100 → 160
    • Cars: 100 → 160
    • Blueprints
      • Passenger Trains: 20 → 30
      • Freight Trains: 12 → 18
      • Buses: 12 → 18
      • Trucks: 8 → 12
  • Improved graphics and frame rate
  • Auto-save and Game Chat support
  • Two new scenarios – Details to be announced.
  • Mouse support for Joy-Con 2 / USB mouse

Watch the announcement trailer below. Visit the official website here.

item.title: Crimson Desert physical edition to be distributed by PLAION
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

Due out in Q1 2026.

PLAION will distribute the physical edition of Pearl Abyss-developed open-world action adventure game Crimson Desert globally when it launches for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam in Q1 2026, the companies announced.

“We are proud to work with Pearl Abyss to bring Crimson Desert to players across the globe,” said PLAION Partners CEO Craig McNicol in a press release. “Our global footprint and experienced territory teams will bring fans the incredible experience of Crimson Desert. This collaboration is a testament to PLAION’s growing commitment to and strength in the Asia Pacific region and highlights our ongoing mission to become a global force in video game publishing.”

Pearl Abyss chief business officer Kevin Kim added, “PLAION is already proving to be a strong partner for Pearl Abyss as we continue to grow in overseas markets. Partnering with PLAION with their global footprint will allow us to bring Crimson Desert to even more fans around the world. We are pleased to partner with a physical game distributor that shares our ambitious vision of an adventure set in the beautiful yet brutal continent of Pywel.”

Here is a brief overview of the game, via PLAION:

Crimson Desert is an open-world action-adventure game set in the beautiful yet brutal world of Pywel. Players follow Kliff, leader of the Greymanes—a band of battle-hardened mercenaries—who must fight to save these lands from an impending catastrophe. As they explore the vast landscapes of Pywel, players will engage in intense battles, defeat formidable monsters, collect valuable loot, and follow the story of the Greymanes’ journey with next-generation visuals.

If you missed it last week, watch 13 minutes of Crimson Desert gameplay from Gamescom 2025 here.

item.title: Atari acquires rights to Ubisoft’s Cold Fear, I Am Alive, Child of Eden, Grow Home, and Grow Up
item.content:encoded:
Atari to explore expanding games to new platforms.

Atari has acquired all intellectual property rights to Ubisoft titles Cold Fear, I Am Alive, Child of Eden, Grow Home, and Grow Up, the companies announced. Atari plans to re-release these titles under its label and explore opportunities to expand their reach through new platforms, new content, and additional distribution channels.

“Millions of players have experienced these worlds over the years, and this will open the door for long time players to revisit those memories while inviting new audiences to discover them for the first time,” said Atari vice president of new business Deborah Papiernik in a press release. “Atari has a rich gaming legacy and deep appreciation for these classic titles, we’re excited to see how they’ll evolve and connect with players in fresh, meaningful ways.”

Atari chairman and CEO Wade Rosen added, “Ubisoft and Atari both have a legacy of crafting worlds that players can fall in love with—games that resonate with generations of players not just for how they played, but for how they made us feel. We’re excited to reintroduce these titles while also exploring ways to expand and evolve these franchises.”

Here is a brief overview of each title:

  • Cold Fear (2005) – A survival horror third-person shooter developed by Darkworks. Originally released for PlayStation 2, Xbox, and PC in 2005. Currently available for PC via Steam.
  • I Am Alive (2012) – An action adventure survival game developed by Ubisoft Shanghai. Originally released for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and PC in 2012. Currently available for PC via Steam.
  • Child of Eden (2011) – A musical rail shooter developed by Q Entertainment and directed by Tetsuya Mizuguchi (Rez, Lumines). Originally released for PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 in 2011.
  • Grow Home (2015) – An adventure platformer developed by Ubisoft Reflections. Originally released for PC via Steam in 2015, followed by PlayStation 4 later that year.
  • Grow Up (2016) – A sequel to Grow Home developed by Ubisoft Reflections. Originally released for PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and PC in 2016.
